docs.lead_paragraph: On the second day of arguments challenging President Obama’s 2010 health care law, conservative members of the Supreme Court asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate, a core provision of the legislation.

headline.seo: Justices Split in Questions on Insurance Mandate
headline.main: In Court, Sharp Questions on Health Care Law’s Mandate
headline.print_headline: Sharp Questions in Court On Health Law Mandate

docs.abstract: Solicitor General Donal B Verrilli Jr faces a barrage of skeptical questions from four of the Supreme Court's more conservative justices about the health care reform law's individual mandate; the tone of the proceedings suggests that a 5-to-4 decision to strike down the law is a live possibility.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY - No flash. No sizzle. No last-minute protests, and no late-night dramatics. This is not how Albany ordinarily works.

headline.main: Without Usual Hubbub, State Budget Deal Is Reached

docs.abstract: New York State Gov Andrew M Cuomo and legislative leaders quickly agree to $132.6 billion budget for state's fiscal year; agreement is a back-to-basics plan that offers lawmakers and Cuomo a mix of victories and defeats at a time when the weak economy has slowed the growth of state revenues. Photo (M)

headline.main: Quietly, a Budget Deal Is Reached in Albany
headline.print_headline: Without Usual Hubbub, State Budget Deal Is Reached

docs.abstract: The final spending plan reflected only modest changes from that proposed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in January. Overall spending will fall for the second straight year, the first time that has happened in at least three decades, according to the governor's office.

headline.main: Mandate's Impact May Be Limited, Report Says

docs.abstract: If the insurance requirement in the health care act is upheld, only 7 percent of the nonelderly population will be forced to purchase new coverage or pay a penalty, according to new research.
docs.snippet: If the insurance requirement in the health care act is upheld, only 7 percent of the nonelderly population will be forced to purchase new coverage or pay a penalty, according to new research.
